title: John Newton Johnson to Walt Whitman, 3 April [1875]
text: Cliff HomeArpil 3 18[75] Walt Whitman The Amana need wish to see. He has been so idle or lazy destitute of acquired knowledge to about of paper would suffice to him of "Philosophy" and Wit.Dont be is a big date man up dear ooyou dooddid what name like me! me write ooyou letter—it sallsay be "fresh and modern" me is Modern Man, onyonly boutabout four five monfsmonths old—but me is not "Average Man"—oo tall[tell] me Average Man, ooyou lie!—Average Man is blame rascal—him not wufworth pickin[picking] up in dethe road if him be tannin tip-toe! May-be if ooyou work him ober[over] free[three] four times, him be wufworthsumtinsomething—but way him is now, him tealsteal, him cheat, him beg, him tell lies—but me is fine ittlelittle "secesh," tuf boy man—me "boo bood[Goo Good]"! me dotgot pentyplenty F. F. G.,—me not tealsteal—me not cheat—me not beg—me not tell lies back lies lies" is all back to us me ittlelittle man boutabout datthat—man me is boutabout datthat, but when say yes yes and when me say no it be no—datsfun sometime but no help it—me will some "white lies" fun some nice Poetry. But do demthem drear fingsthings, me tancan fight and tanfounfind dethe backblack-heart bobolitions! head niggers! what em doodgood for town and totton for chibalry[chivalry] white mans? Uncle Walt: me is been treat bad—papa not gibgive me no name 'till me mos' freethree monfsmonths old—him not like name him babys for live mans—him faid live mans do bad finfsthings and make babies shamed—but me finkthink ooyou nebernever do no bad fingsthings, man what talk doodgood like ooyou wont nebernever do no bad fingsthings—papa not like bobolitions neiderneither, but may-be ooyou not bobolitions, may-be ooyou onyonly make-believe, may-be onyonly also dust in of dem bobolitions rounaround boutabout ooyou, for fatter , and rake in dertheir money, (datthat money dethe Tariff tealsteal from doodgood mans to backblack-heart bobolitions datthat case , me say "go head em fatter em, an' fatter em pile from em'—denthen ooyou here aferafter ooyou datthat line, an' build dood house on an' me an' ooyou will togeddertogether enough to dethe old bobolitions boutabout something ooyou out of dertheir money—datthat we put my boo flag) on top house an' fap, an' fap, an' fap—an' we will binbring big fiddles too, for play Dixie! DenThen if noderanother war tomescomes we will be taptainscaptains of Ku Klux banditti, an' me go east, an' ooyou go west, an' we will clean out all bobolitions an' wooly head niggers. Tause'Cause me is doodgood fightin tockstock; me fight beryvery well when me dotgot no place for run to; me hunt for last ditch, but if em catch me forebefore me get derethere, me will say me is old woman!But Uncle Walt: me dont know if me wants see ooyou—tomebodysomebody say ooyou not talk much tomebodysomebody say ooyou let oderother folks do mosmost talking—what ooyou datthat way for? ittlelittle man tould[told] me datthat longalong widwith ooyou datthat way—him mighty , but him finkthink ittlelittlebite first, but see much books, him lazy , him not dotgot big pile , nor finkthink fine closeclothes, nor big money ittlelittle secesh man onyonly dotgot mosmost doodgood sense, sheriff brave heart, an' ittlelittle . What for ooyou want see ittlelittle ? Does ooyou want hug him neck? does ooyou want hold him by him hand? Uncle Walt: ooyou mus'must not be tongue-tied.—Me is not been sick now, onyonly , till me four monfsmonths old—denthen big ittlelittle boy take me in wind an' me habhave told an' feber freethree days, but me tonquerconquer him—what for me dotgot "gymnastic" muddermother if me tantcant tonquerconquer told an' feber? me bully ittlelittle boy—and ittlelittle Jersey—boo—coat boy say "union" to me me tancan whip him quicker'n him Banner an' Pennant tancan say "fap", "fap", "fap"—ooyou bet!Me not want presents what money tancan buy—ooyou musmust gibgive datthat sort to odeold ittlelittle Walt Whitmans—but ooyou mus' gibgive love to ittlelittle secesh mans. Now, nameWalt Whitman XX≠IIXX! me pile him something be him doodgood nuffenough. John Newton Johnson to Walt Whitman, 3 April [1875]
